Award.AwardTitle: US-UK Collab: Ecological and socio-economic factors impacting maintenance and dissemination of antibiotic resistance in the Greater Serengeti Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
Antibiotic resistance in bacteria is a significant challenge to both human and veterinary medicine. The problem is both multifaceted and global. Resistance continues to evolve and amplify at local scales while travel and trade bring antibiotic resistance to the global arena. This project will produce crucial but currently missing knowledge about the mechanisms by which ecological and socioeconomic factors impact the fate of antibiotic resistance traits. The research will be carried out in three ecologically distinct zones of the greater Serengeti ecosystem of Tanzania by a multi-disciplinary and international team with expertise in molecular biology, disease ecology, quantitative modeling, socio-economic and ethnographic disciplines. It includes researchers from the Paul G. Allen School for Global Animal Health and the Department of Anthropology at Washington State University in the United States; the University of Glasgow and the Royal Veterinary College of the University of London in the United Kingdom; and the Tanzania Wildlife Research Institute and the Zonal Veterinary Investigation Centre in Tanzania.

The goal is to understand how antibiotic resistance is impacted by patterns of connectivity within and between communities, arising from shared resources such as water; population density and its effect on interactions between human and livestock; and animal movements via trade between communities. The central hypothesis is that the prevalence and diversity of antibiotic resistance in human and livestock populations is primarily explained by the dissemination and persistence of resistance within and between various host populations, rather than by direct use of antibiotics, leading to similar antibiotic resistance patterns and gene pools in human and livestock populations. Antibiotic resistance characterization of 64,000 isolates of E. coli from humans, livestock and wildlife and molecular characterization of a subset of these isolates will be carried out on samples from 30 study communities. Socio-economic and ethnographic data will be collected at both the household and community levels. Besides providing information about antibiotic use behaviors, these data will be incorporated into an ecological modeling process that will investigate the diversity of resistance traits and their spatio-temporal distribution and probable dissemination pathways between reservoirs.

The project is based on the "One Health" premise that simultaneously considers both human and animal health and welfare. This is particularly important in rural communities where economic and food security is highly dependent on the health and welfare of livestock. The findings from this project will have direct implications for policy design and execution to control the global emergence and spread of antibiotic resistance, a challenge that transcends national and international borders. The project also supports international research collaboration and the training of postdoctoral researchers and graduate students in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Tanzania.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antimicrobial resistance is a global public health crisis that is ultimately driven by antibiotic use, but antibiotic use is a poor predictor for when an individual person, animal or household will be colonized with antibiotic-resistant bacteria. A second dimension to this problem is the intersection between people and animals. In high-income countries where people do not commonly interact with food animals, there is generally poor overlap between drug-resistant bacteria from people and livestock. We surmise that this is very different from low-income countries where veterinary and medical antibiotic use is unregulated, while people and livestock interact much more closely on a daily basis. This study was designed to identify risk factors for carriage of antibiotic-resistant gut bacteria (E. coli) by people and animals in northern Tanzania. These communities were selected because they provided a wide diversity of cultural context, including a diversity of animal husbandry practices, diet, socio-economic status, etc. We interviewed over 300 households in three distinct ethnic groups (Maasai, Chagga and Arusha) and collected fecal and milk samples at a subset of these households, isolated bacteria (>70,000), and characterized these isolates for their resistance to nine antibiotics. While antibiotic use in livestock was common for Maasai households, we found that antibiotic use in both veterinary and medical contexts was a poor predictor for colonization with antibiotic-resistant bacteria in both people and animals. Instead, we found that mixing animals from different herds and sharing water sources with people and animals were important risk factors for antibiotic-resistance in Arusha and Chagga households. The most important risk factor in Maasai households was consumption of raw milk, which appeared to serve as a vehicle to ingest antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

 

One major conclusion from this work is that cultural context needs to be considered when designing interventions to reduce the burden of antibiotic resistant bacteria in different communities. For example, interventions in Maasai households might focus on milk handling and consumption practices whereas this focus would have much less impact in the other communities. That is, one-size-fits-all solutions are unlikely to be impactful. Secondly, based on both antibiotic-resistance testing and molecular analyses, bacterial transmission appears widespread within and between the communities, consistent with significant hygiene and sanitation challenges. This point is critical to emphasize because most efforts to limit antibiotic resistance focus on how people use antibiotics (e.g., stewardship practices in hospitals), but if transmission is not controlled at the community level these organisms will spread widely regardless of local antibiotic use practices. Finally, we identified a neighborhood effect whereby having neighbors with a high prevalence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria increased the probability of carrying resistant bacteria regardless of household practices. This finding is important because it shows how neighborhood effects can might limit interventions if adoption of best practices is variable between households in these communities.

 

Beyond these major findings, we elected to use the raw milk findings from Maasai communities to develop novel milk treatment strategies that would be consistent with local beliefs and milk handling practices. Milk pasteurization involves heating milk to approximately 70-degrees Celsius for about 30 seconds. Pilot interviews showed that if a reliable method was available to measure milk temperature, pasteurization would be far more acceptable to food preparers in Maasai households compared with boiling milk. Consequently, we developed a digital thermometer that displays a bright LED when milk reaches pasteurization temperature over an open fire. Because pasteurization produces a more desirable product, we surmise that making it simpler to pasteurize milk will result in increased milk consumption and improved nutritional status of children in particular. Furthermore, because less heat is needed when not boiling milk, pasteurization has the potential to reduce fuel demands in areas where firewood is an important resource. Pilot testing across four villages demonstrated that the digital thermometers were acceptable to most cooks. Adoption of such technologies will depend on how these are introduced to these communities. We found that short-term adoption was significantly greater when the digital thermometers were introduced via a narrative story about their use and benefits, as opposed to a technical description about safe food practices. Further work is needed to develop strategies for propagating such interventions in a cost-effective and sustainable fashion in dispersed communities that have low rates of literacy.

 

Beyond increasing our understanding of the importance of cultural practices and microbial transmission, this project also engaged a broad interdisciplinary team including microbiologists, veterinarians, medical anthropologists and mathematical modelers. Training and scholarship engaged at all levels including local field workers, undergraduate, DVM and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and multiple investigators at institutions in the United States, United Kingdom, and the United Republic of Tanzania.
